title: Chapter 6: Modeling Random Events
text:
NoteProbability Distribution (PDF)



A probability distribution is a tool, in the form of a table or a graph, that tells us

All possible outcomes of a random experiment.
The probability of each outcome.









NoteFeatures of a Probability Distribution




All \(P(X)\) must be between 0 and 1.
The sum of all \(P(X)\) values must equal 1.









NoteDiscrete and Continuous Variables




Discrete variable: Numerical values that you can list or count.
Continuous variable: Numerical values that cannot be listed or counted because they occur over a continuous range of values.









TipExample 6.1.1.




QuestionAnswer


Determine the variable type.

Number of siblings you have
Height of basketball players
Number of cars owned by a household
Number of pets owned by a student
Temperature of St. Augustine on January 1st, 2000
Wait time in a doctor’s office



a. Discrete b. Continuous c. Discrete d. Discrete e. Continuous f. Continuous











NoteDiscrete Variables



Since the values of a discrete variable cannot be listed, a probability distribution using a table (or spike graph) is more useful for a discrete variable.








NoteContinuous Variables



The graph of a continuous probability distribution is called a density curve or probability density function* (pdf). These graphs have an area under the curve that must equal to 1. Therefore, the area under the curve represents the probability.
The plot below illustrates the probability \(P(X \geqslant x_1)\) for a normal curve.

title: Chapter 6: Modeling Random Events
text:
Section 6.1 Examples






TipExample 1




QuestionAnswer


Consider the random variable \(X\) where \(X =\) number of stars given by a randomly selected book reviewer. The probability distribution of the number of stars is shown below. Estimate the probability that a randomly selected reviewer gave a given book a three-star rating.











The probability value for three-star rating is 0.11.











TipExample 2




QuestionAnswer


When an unfair coin is tossed, the probability that it lands on heads is 80%, and the probability that it lands on tails is 20%. Let \(H\) to mean heads and \(T\) tails.

List all possible outcomes when flipping two unfair coins.
Are the coin tosses independent of one another? Why?
Complete the table below.





\(P(HH)\)
\(P(HT)\)
\(P(TH)\)
\(P(TT)\)
Total




Probability









Let \(X =\) number of coins that land on heads out of two tosses, complete the following probability distribution table.




\(X\)
0
1
2
Total




\(P(X)\)









a. There are 4 distinct outcomes you can get from flipping 2 coins. \[
  \{ HH, HT, TH, HH \}
\] b. The coin tosses are independent of each other, because the outcome of a toss does not depend on the outcome of the previous toss. c. We need to first calculate the following probabilities. Assuming that the coin tosses are independent events. Then \[
\begin{align}
  P(HH) &= P(H) \cdot P(H) = 0.8 \cdot 0.8 = 0.64\\
  P(HT) &= P(H) \cdot P(T) = 0.8 \cdot 0.2 = 0.16\\
  P(TH) &= P(T) \cdot P(H) = 0.2 \cdot 0.8 = 0.16\\
  P(TT) &= P(T) \cdot P(T) = 0.2 \cdot 0.2 = 0.04
\end{align}
\] Finally, adding these probability together, we have \[
  P(HH) + P(HT) + P(TH) + P(TT) = 0.64 + 0.16 + 0.16 + 0.04 = 1
\] d. First observe that \[
\begin{align}
  X &= \text{event with 0 heads} = \{ TT \},\\
  X &= \text{event with 1 heads} = \{ HT, TH \},\\
  X &= \text{event with 2 heads} = \{ HH \}
\end{align}
\] Therefore \[
\begin{align}
  P(X = 0) &= 0.04,\\
  P(X = 1) &= P(HT) + P(TH) = 0.16 + 0.16 = 0.32,\\
  P(X = 2) &= P(HH) = 0.64
\end{align}
\] And the sum is \[
  P(X = 0) + P(X = 1) + P(X = 2) = 0.04 + 0.32 + 0.64 = 1.
\]











TipExample 3




QuestionAnswer


This probability density curve shows the probability of wait times before service at a coffee shop. The shaded area represents the probability of a wait time between 0 and 2 minutes.

What is the minimum wait time at the coffee shop?
What is the maximum wait time at the coffee shop?
Based on the plot, approximately what is the probability that someone will wait between 0 and 2 minutes?












a. The minimum wait time is 0 minutes. b. The maximum wait time is 5 minutes. c. The probability that someone will wait between 0 and 2 minutes is somewhat less than 50%.











TipExample 4




QuestionAnswer


A bus arrives at a certain stop every 12 minutes. The graph below shows the probability distribution for the continuous random variable \(X =\) wait time before the bus arrives. This is an example of a uniform distribution, that is, a distribution in which every possibility for the random variable \(X\) is equally likely. Use this distribution to find the probability of a wait time between 4 and 10 minutes.











To find the probability of waiting between 4 and 10 minutes, we simply find the area of of the rectangle that is between 4 and 10. The width of the red rectangle is \(10 - 4 = 6\) and its height is \(0.0833\), so \[
  P(4 \leqslant X \leqslant 10) = 6 \times 0.0833 = 0.4998 \approx 0.5
\]




















TipExample 5




QuestionAnswer


Suppose an instructor designs lessons so that the class lengths are uniformly distributed between 72.0 and 77.0 minutes. That is, any time between 72.0 min and 77.0 min is possible and all the possible values are equally likely. If we let \(X\) be the random variable representing the length of that class, then the random variable \(X\) has a distribution that can be graphed below.

Is the length of the class a continuous or a discrete random variable?
Can a probability distribution (a table) be created for this random variable?
The probability density function for the random variable of class time is given below. What is the total area under the curve?
Determine the probability that the class runs over 75.5 minutes, i.e., \(P(X \geqslant 75.5)\).












a. The length of class time is a continuous variable. b. Since the variable is continuous, a probability distribution table cannot be created. c. The total area under the curve is the total area of the entire rectangle: \[
  \text{area} = (77 - 72) \times 0.2 = 5 \times 0.2 = 1
\] d. The probability \(P(X \geqslant 75)\) is the area of the shaded region that is between 75 and 77: \[
  P(X \geqslant 75) = (77 - 75) \times 0.2 = 2 \times 0.2 = 0.4
\]

title: Chapter 6: Modeling Random Events
text:
The Normal Distribution Model






NoteNotation




Mean of a probability distribution: \(\mu\) (“mu”)
Standard deviation of a probability distribution: \(\sigma\) (“sigma”)
A normal distribution with mean \(\mu\) and standard deviation \(\sigma\): \(N(\mu, \sigma)\).









NoteThe Normal Distribution



Every normal curve:

Is symmetric about its mean.
Has its peak at the mean.
Is bell-shaped.

All normal curves are characterized by two parameters: population mean \(\mu\) and population standard deviation \(\sigma\).








TipExample 6.2.1.




QuestionAnswer


Answer the following questions using the plot below.

What is the mean (\(\mu\)) of these normal distributions?
Approximate the standard deviation (\(\sigma\)) of these normal distributions.
What is the total area under each curve?


x <- seq(-6, 6, length.out = 1201)
df <- tibble(x = x)

ggplot(df, aes(x)) +
  # Red: N(0, 1)
  geom_line(aes(y = dnorm(x, mean = 0, sd = 1)),
            color = "red", linewidth = 1.2) +
  # Blue: N(0, 2)
  geom_line(aes(y = dnorm(x, mean = 0, sd = 2)),
            color = "blue", linewidth = 1.2) +
  # X-axis: ticks at each integer from -6 to 6
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = -6:6, limits = c(-6, 6)) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = NULL) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(
    # Remove y-axis entirely
    axis.line.y  = element_blank(),
    axis.text.y  = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.y = element_blank(),
    axis.title.y = element_blank()
  )










a. Both curves have a mean of \(\mu = 0\). b. The standard deviation of the red curve is approximately 1, whereas the standard deviation of the blue curve is approximately 2. c. The total area under any normal curve is equal to 1.
